Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying a qualitative test despite meeting quantitative physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of 1178 days of physical presence in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed, application remitted for redetermination
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of citizenship application denial
Court_Ruling: Federal Court found error in the Citizenship Judge's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship Judge ignored reliable evidence and applied qualitative lifestyle assessment
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous application of the qualitative test from Koo
Legal_Standard: Quantitative physical presence requirement under s. 5(1)(c)
Assessment_Factor: Days of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal by way of judicial review
Evidence_Used: Documentation showing 1178 days of physical presence
Evidence_Assessed: Reliable evidence of physical presence was provided but disregarded
Relief_Sought: Allowance of appeal and remittal for redetermination
Governing_Rule: If quantitative requirement is met, qualitative test should not apply
Outcome: Appeal allowed, case remitted to another Citizenship Judge
Cause_Description: Applicant's citizenship application was denied due to alleged failure to meet residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Citizenship Judge failed to properly consider documented physical presence
Evidence_Issues: Rejection of clear evidence without justification
Evidence_Assessment: Physical presence evidence was sufficient and credible
Decision_Rationale: Error in law: applying qualitative test when quantitative threshold was met
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to acknowledge and assess reliable documentary evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective fulfillment of statutory physical presence requirement
